column8: Benjamins not in London, update ref

I can see that this word is used in a number of works related to translation, including Gottlieb, and I can guess what it means, but it's extremely rare and I can't find it in any dictionaries. Consider the far more common *multimodal* or *multimedia* unless they connote something unintended.
I will stop marking this. Change here and throughout.
Make these changes throughout. I will stop commenting on them.
ever since what/when? If you keep *since*, use present perfect *has lacked*.
please insert an article here. It sounds quite strange without.
please use a reference equal to that one used for the other film: title, year, channel.
The following part should be put in brackets as done in other passages in this article.
consider *language*
The slash suggests an alternative. Replace with *to*.
use *number* for countable nouns like *films*
Consider the less informal *try to make*
replace with *just as with*
*include a limit*
Insert *about*
and following
In this figure and ff, y-axis and legend font is too big.
In what sense would a narration have an OT? How could it be shortened and alterered? An example might help.
*catering* requires a *to* PP complement here, not a direct object.
consider *generally*
In ....? proceedings, thesis? Alternatively, you can cite  Moran, Siobhan. 2012 'The effect of linguistic variation on subtitle reception.' Eye tracking in audiovisual translation, 183.
*and therefore*
Consider *intellectual property rights* to avoid confusing a particular copyright with the general rights.
avoid the dummy subject: *lack of standardised norms can be criticised*
so exactly 6 seconds?
why is experience written in capital letters here?
no space
also below
Having already introduced the term *diasemiotic*, is *diamesic* also necessary?
use genitive *its*
The third step, 'operationalisation' appears as 'Concept' in the figure.
*consider* takes predicative complements, among others, but not *as* PP complements. Remove *as* or replace it with *to be*.
*As is visible*
*feel* takes predicative complements, not *as* PP complements. Strike *as*.
comma plus *which*
Is there any hyperreference to be set here?
rather than putting *while* here, with a very long subordinate clause, consider striking it and using *but* between clauses.
I suggest you to put in italics: W (W = 1675877) p (p < 0.001) p (As the error probability p is clearly below..)
Is this the content of footnote 2? If so, it shouldn't appear here.
What is born? The subject of the main clause is *viewers*, but presumably it is something like the need to split their attention which is born?

Single quotation marks are used only for linguistic meaning.

consider *allow for shorter eye movements between lines*
*Dubbing*
replace with *or*
Use present-tense *reasons*, not the participle, to match *give* in the other coordinate clause.
anachronistic and irrelevant

the first two coordinates are NPs, while this is a VP. Strike *offer* for parallel structure.
*at the opera*
Consider placing this directly after *guidelines*
add *the*
Consider *facilitates access for*, which avoids the unintended meaning of giving somebody access to the audience.

Update ref

This enumeration works evenly fine without the 'and'.
This is the second time you've mentioned *linguistics*, but the word means 'The scientific study of language and its structure'. Perhaps you mean *linguistic elements* or just *language*?
Even for an academic text, this is a remakably uninviting opening sentence.
1, 2, 3, 4 on the x-axis are missing
use comma plus *which* for supplementary relatives.
While this may be familiar to people in translation studies, it will be unfamiliar to most linguistcs. Consider defining  it.
